Package mz

Class Tim

java.lang.Object
mz.SortComparable
mz.Merge
mz.Tim
All Implemented Interfaces:
InsertionInterface<Comparable>, MergeInterface<Comparable>, Sort<Comparable>
Direct Known Subclasses:
IntroTim
public class Tim extends Merge implements InsertionInterface<Comparable>
Tim Sort is a hybrid sorting algorithm that combines the strengths of Merge Sort and Insertion Sort to achieve efficient and stable sorting. The default sorting algorithm in Java's Arrays.sort() method.
Since:
1.0
Author:
Magyar Zolt√°n

  • Constructor Details

    • Tim

      public Tim()
      Tim Sort:
      Is a hybrid sorting algorithm that combines the strengths of Merge Sort and Insertion Sort to achieve efficient and stable sorting. The default sorting algorithm in Java's Arrays.sort() method.

      Example:
      1. Insertion Sort: Tim Sort starts by dividing the input array into small chunks or "runs." It uses Insertion Sort to sort these runs individually. Insertion Sort is chosen for small chunks because it performs well on already partially sorted data.
      2. Merge Step: After the runs are sorted, Tim Sort begins merging them. It repeatedly merges pairs of runs into larger sorted runs until there is only one run remaining. The merging process is similar to the merge step in Merge Sort.
      3. Run Size Determination: Tim Sort employs a concept called "galloping" to determine the size of runs during the merging process. It dynamically adjusts the run size based on the distribution of the data, aiming to minimize the number of comparisons and movements. This adaptive nature of Tim Sort allows it to adapt to different types of input data.
      4. Stability: Tim Sort is a stable sorting algorithm, meaning that it preserves the relative order of elements with equal values. It ensures that equal elements maintain their original order during the sorting process.
      5. Optimization Techniques: Tim Sort incorporates various optimizations to improve performance. These include the use of a temporary buffer array during merging, reducing the number of comparisons by exploiting sorted subsequences, and minimizing data movements.
      Note:
      Tim Sort is designed to perform well on various types of real-world data, including arrays with a mix of already sorted and unsorted elements, as well as datasets with duplicate elements. It aims to minimize the number of comparisons and data movements while providing good worst-case time complexity.

      The time complexity of Tim Sort is O(n log n) in the worst case. This occurs when the input data is in reverse order or has no pre-existing order. In practice, Tim Sort often performs better than the worst-case time complexity due to its ability to efficiently handle partially sorted and duplicate elements.

      Tim Sort's ability to handle different types of input data, its stability, and its worst-case time complexity of O(n log(n)) make it a widely used and reliable sorting algorithm in many programming languages and applications.

      Property:
      Worst Case Complexity: O(n log(n))
      Best Case Complexity: O(n log(n))
      Average Case Complexity: O(n log(n))
      Auxiliary Space: O(n)
      Stability: Yes
      See Also:
      • IntroDPQTim
      • IntroTim

    • timInc

      protected void timInc(Comparable[] array)
      timInc that takes an array of Comparable objects. This method performs an incremental variant of the Tim Sort algorithm to sort the specified range of the array.
      • The method starts by initializing the variables n and minRun. The n variable is assigned the value of the array.length, which represents the exclusive upper bound of the range to be sorted. The minRun variable is assigned the result of the minRunLength method called with the MIN_MERGE constant.
      • The first for loop iterates over the range from 0 to n with a step size of minRun. It calls the insertionInc method to perform an incremental insertion sort on the subarray from i to (Math.min((i + MIN_MERGE), n) - 1). This step is used to ensure that each small run within the array is sorted.
      • The second for loop performs the merging step of the Tim Sort algorithm. It starts with a size value of minRun and doubles the value of size in each iteration. It iterates over the range from 0 to n with a step size of (2 * size). Within each iteration, it determines the mid index mid and the upper bound index j of the current subarray. If mid is less than j, it calls the mergeInc method to merge the subarrays from i to mid and from (mid + 1) to j. This step merges adjacent sorted subarrays together until the entire range is sorted.
      timInc method uses incremental insertion sort to sort small runs within the array and then performs merging steps to combine adjacent sorted subarrays. This incremental variant of Tim Sort provides efficient sorting for arrays that may already have some degree of ordering or partial sorting.
      Parameters:
      array - to be arranged.
      See Also:
      • MIN_MERGE
      • minRunLength(int)
      • InsertionInterface.insertionInc(Comparable[], int, int)
      • MergeInterface.mergeInc(Comparable[], int, int, int)

    • timDec

      protected void timDec(Comparable[] array)
      timDec that takes an array of Comparable objects. This method performs a decremental variant of the Tim Sort algorithm to sort the specified range of the array.
      • The method starts by initializing the variables n and minRun. The n variable is assigned the value of the array.length, which represents the exclusive upper bound of the range to be sorted. The minRun variable is assigned the result of the minRunLength method called with the MIN_MERGE constant.
      • The first for loop iterates over the range from 0 to n with a step size of minRun. It calls the insertionDec method to perform an incremental insertion sort on the subarray from i to (Math.min((i + MIN_MERGE), n) - 1). This step is used to ensure that each small run within the array is sorted.
      • The second for loop performs the merging step of the Tim Sort algorithm. It starts with a size value of minRun and doubles the value of size in each iteration. It iterates over the range from 0 to n with a step size of (2 * size). Within each iteration, it determines the mid index mid and the upper bound index j of the current subarray. If mid is less than j, it calls the mergeDec method to merge the subarrays from i to mid and from (mid + 1) to j. This step merges adjacent sorted subarrays together until the entire range is sorted.
      timDec method uses decremental insertion sort to sort small runs within the array and then performs merging steps to combine adjacent sorted subarrays. This decremental variant of Tim Sort provides efficient sorting for arrays that may already have some degree of ordering or partial sorting.
      Parameters:
      array - to be arranged.

    • timInc

      protected void timInc(Comparable[] array, int left, int right)
      timInc that takes an array of Comparable objects, an integer left, and an integer right as input. This method performs an incremental variant of the Tim Sort algorithm to sort the specified range of the array.
      • The method starts by initializing the variable minRun. The right parameter, which represents the exclusive upper bound of the range to be sorted. The minRun variable is assigned the result of the minRunLength method called with the MIN_MERGE constant.
      • The first for loop iterates over the range from 0 to right with a step size of minRun. It calls the insertionInc method to perform an incremental insertion sort on the subarray from i to (Math.min((i + MIN_MERGE), right) - 1). This step is used to ensure that each small run within the array is sorted.
      • The second for loop performs the merging step of the Tim Sort algorithm. It starts with a size value of minRun and doubles the value of size in each iteration. It iterates over the range from left to right with a step size of (2 * size). Within each iteration, it determines the mid index mid and the upper bound index j of the current subarray. If mid is less than j, it calls the mergeInc method to merge the subarrays from i to mid and from (mid + 1) to j. This step merges adjacent sorted subarrays together until the entire range is sorted.
      timInc method uses incremental insertion sort to sort small runs within the array and then performs merging steps to combine adjacent sorted subarrays. This incremental variant of Tim Sort provides efficient sorting for arrays that may already have some degree of ordering or partial sorting.
      Parameters:
      array - to be arranged.
      left - the value in the array must be smaller than a right parameter.
      right - the value in the array must be greater than a left parameter.
      See Also:
      • MIN_MERGE
      • minRunLength(int)
      • InsertionInterface.insertionInc(Comparable[], int, int)
      • MergeInterface.mergeInc(Comparable[], int, int, int)

    • timDec

      protected void timDec(Comparable[] array, int left, int right)
      timDec that takes an array of Comparable objects, an integer left, and an integer right as input. This method performs a decremental variant of the Tim Sort algorithm to sort the specified range of the array.
      • The method starts by initializing the variable minRun. The right parameter, which represents the exclusive upper bound of the range to be sorted. The minRun variable is assigned the result of the minRunLength method called with the MIN_MERGE constant.
      • The first for loop iterates over the range from 0 to right with a step size of minRun. It calls the insertionDec method to perform an incremental insertion sort on the subarray from i to (Math.min((i + MIN_MERGE), right) - 1). This step is used to ensure that each small run within the array is sorted.
      • The second for loop performs the merging step of the Tim Sort algorithm. It starts with a size value of minRun and doubles the value of size in each iteration. It iterates over the range from left to right with a step size of (2 * size). Within each iteration, it determines the mid index mid and the upper bound index j of the current subarray. If mid is less than j, it calls the mergeDec method to merge the subarrays from i to mid and from (mid + 1) to j. This step merges adjacent sorted subarrays together until the entire range is sorted.
      timDec method uses decremental insertion sort to sort small runs within the array and then performs merging steps to combine adjacent sorted subarrays. This decremental variant of Tim Sort provides efficient sorting for arrays that may already have some degree of ordering or partial sorting.
      Parameters:
      array - to be arranged.
      left - the value in the array must be smaller than a right parameter.
      right - the value in the array must be greater than a left parameter.
      See Also:

    • minRunLength

      protected int minRunLength(int n)
      minRunLength that takes an integer n as input and returns an integer value. This method calculates the minimum run length based on the value of n.
      • The assert statement checks if n is greater than or equal to 0. If this condition is false, an AssertionError will be thrown, indicating a violation of the assumed precondition. It serves as a check to ensure that the input is valid.
      • An integer variable r is initialized to 0. This variable will be used to store the least significant bit of n.
      • The while loop continues as long as n is greater than or equal to a constant value MIN_MERGE. This condition implies that the loop will execute until n becomes smaller than MIN_MERGE.
      • Inside the loop, the least significant bit of n is obtained using the bitwise AND operator & with 1 (n & 1). The result is then combined with r using the bitwise OR operator | (r |= (n & 1)). This operation sets the least significant bit of r to the same value as the least significant bit of n.
      • Next, n is right-shifted by 1 (n >>= 1), effectively dividing it by 2. This is done to gradually reduce the value of n in each iteration until it becomes smaller than MIN_MERGE.
      • Finally, outside the loop, the value of n is added to r (n + r), and the result is returned as the minimum run length.
      minRunLength method calculates the minimum run length based on the input value n by repeatedly dividing n by 2 until it becomes smaller than MIN_MERGE. The least significant bit of each division is stored in r, and at the end, r is added to the remaining value of n to obtain the final minimum run length.
      Parameters:
      n - the minimum run length based on the input value.
      Returns:
      the result as the minimum run length.
      See Also:
      • MIN_MERGE
